course_title: Topics in French Thought: Civ.: Unconscious Impacts
seats: Seats: Maximum Enrollment: 18 / Seats Avail: 12Waitlist Total: 0
class_notes:
FREN 471W "Unconscious Impacts" 
Claire Nouvet  (MW 2:30-3:45 in person)
Content: Slips of the tongue, phobias, anxieties: what Freud identified as the 'unconscious' makes its presence felt through various disruptions that conscious thought does not know how to explain to itself. To understand why the unconscious is formed and how it works is the task that Freud set for psychoanalytic thought. Such exploration led to a radical rethinking of sexuality and of the very notion of the 'self.' As we shall see, psychoanalysis extends and redefines the notion of 'sexuality' as it traces its impact on mental life. It also unsettles the conception of the self as a unified and monolithic construct to propose instead a dynamic conception of subjectivity as well as complex accounts of its formation. 
Readings may include texts by Freud, Laplanche, Lacan, Dolto, Winnicott, and Pontalis.  Texts will be available either electronically or through PEP archives (which can be accessed via Emory University library).
course_description: Taught in English, this course examines major French and Francophone intellectual developments, theoretical paradigms and critical methodologies.
prerequisites: FREN 310, FREN 314 and two 300 level FREN courses, or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.
